thread.title: Foothill girls tennis roundup: Canyon makes its case
thread.title_full: Foothill girls tennis roundup: Canyon makes its case

author: Mason Nesbitt
title: Foothill girls tennis roundup: Canyon makes its case
text:
Foothill girls tennis roundup: Canyon makes its case Valencia finishes league 10-0; West Ranch finishes second Posted: October 22, 2015 9:33   22, 2015 9:33 p.m. Canyon's Katrina DeGuzman returns a shot against Saugus at Saugus High on Thursday. Signal photo by Dan Watson Saugus sophomore Ada Hanamaikai runs to return a shot against Canyon at Saugus on Thursday. Signal photo by Dan Watson Canyon’s Natalie Tseng returns a shot against Saugus on Thursday at Saugus High. Signal photo by Dan Watson 
The coaches knew. Most of the players knew. 
But Canyon High senior Natalie Tseng didn’t know. 
She wasn’t aware her final set against Saugus sophomore Ada Hanamaikai would not only decide Thursday’s match but, in all likelihood, determine whether the Cowboys’ playoff hopes remained alive. 
Apparently, she didn’t need to, winning the tight set and lifting Canyon girls tennis to a 9-9 (72-66 in games) win at Saugus High that has the Cowboys in position for a possible CIF postseason at-large bid. 
It would be Canyon’s first playoff appearance since 2000. 
“Right after (the set) my team bombarded me and told me,” Tseng said. “The tears came down. The group hug. Just tears of joy. I’m glad to share the moment with my teammates this senior year.” 
Tseng didn’t have much to celebrate with teammates in her first three varsity seasons, including an 0-10 league run in 2014. 
But behind No. 1 single Katrina DeGuzman (who swept three sets Thursday, all 6-0), the Cowboys (8-8 overall, 4-6 in Foothill) have made major strides this season, highlighted by a collective third-place finish at Valencia’s Fall Brawl. 
It was up to Tseng on Thursday to keep the good times rolling. 
Saugus’ Megan Cho and Carlie Ozaki had won their third-round doubles set 6-1 to put the Centurions ahead 9-8 in sets. But Canyon led 65-61 in games, with only Tseng and Hanamaikai still playing. 
Hanamaikai, regularly a JV player and playing in her first varsity match, came from behind to tie the set 5-5, but Tseng won the final two games. 
“I’m proud of her,” Saugus head coach Ken Jeffris said of Hanamaikai. “There was a lot of pressure. She did everything she could do, and they got us again.” 
The again he referred to is the teams’ first meeting this season, which Canyon won 9-9 (72-62 in games). 
Thursday’s matchup had more on the line, as a Saugus win would’ve put the teams in a tie for fourth place and put both squads’ playoff hopes in doubt. 
Canyon isn’t guaranteed a spot, as Saugus finished in fourth place with a 9-8 overall record in 2014, making the playoffs only in the former. 
“It’s still rewarding to have a chance,” Canyon head coach Richard Bristow said of the uncertainty. 
Ozaki and Cho won their other two sets 6-0 for Saugus (6-11, 2-8). 
And DeGuzman ran her league record to 30-0 on the year. 
Valencia 13, Hart 5 
The Vikings, already crowned outright Foothill League champions on Tuesday, capped off their second straight 10-0 run through league on Thursday at Hart High. 
Valencia (16-3, 10-0) won eight of nine doubles sets, led by a sweep from its No. 1 team of Lauren Wolf and Gianna Benitez. 
Vikings Amanda Tabanera and Jennifer Shin each won two sets, losing only to Hart No. 1 Natalia Munoz. 
Munoz, a senior, swept her three sets to finish her regular-season league career unbeaten. 
Hart finished in third place with a 9-8 overall record and a 6-4 league mark. 
West Ranch 18, Golden Valley 0 
The Wildcats (14-3, 8-2) lost just seven games on the day, led by three 6-0 sweeps each from Una Stanisavljevic and the pairing of Cori Raffish and Quinterra Walter-Eze. 
Emily Andrews and Joan Kim both won three sets in singles. 
The Grizzlies finished the year 1-16 overall and 0-10 in league.
